title: 111_hr2111
content: The Act is titled the "Congressional Commission on Financial Accountability and Preparedness Act of 2009". It establishes the Congressional Commission on Financial Accountability and Preparedness. The Congressional Commission on Financial Accountability and Preparedness was established in the legislative branch to investigate the 2008 financial market breakdown, evaluate evidence from relevant agencies, determine if fraud leads were pursued diligently, and provide a comprehensive account of the circumstances surrounding the financial crisis. The Congressional Commission on Financial Accountability and Preparedness was established to investigate the 2008 financial market breakdown, evaluate evidence from relevant agencies, and provide recommendations for future financial crisis prevention. The Commission will review actions leading up to the breakdown and submit regular monthly progress reports to Congress. The Commission will report on events, actions, and transparency leading to the 2008 financial market breakdown. The Commission will submit a final report to Congress detailing its findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative or administrative action. Additionally, a special report on corporate abuse of taxpayer funds will be provided to Congress. The Commission will submit a special report to Congress on any corporate abuse of taxpayer funds and analyze the effectiveness of the regulatory system in overseeing financial system participants and protecting consumers. Additionally, a special report will be submitted on fiduciary negligence, fraudulent behavior, poor corporate governance, obstructionism, or media manipulation by relevant corporate officers and government officials. The Commission consists of 5 members. The Commission consists of 5 members appointed by various leaders. Each member will be paid at a daily rate equivalent to the annual rate. Members of the Commission are paid at a daily rate equal to the annual rate of basic pay for level I of the Executive Schedule. Full-time federal employees or Members of Congress serving on the Commission cannot receive additional pay. Travel expenses, including per diem, are provided according to applicable provisions. A quorum consists of four members, but hearings can be held with fewer. The Commission may appoint personnel and fix their pay, procure temporary services, and request assistance from federal agencies' personnel on a reimbursable basis. Meetings are called by the Chairperson or a majority of members, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, administer oaths, and obtain necessary information from US departments and agencies. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission has the authority to obtain information from US departments and agencies, issue subpoenas, receive required reports, and will terminate after 1 year from the enactment of the Act. The Commission established by this Act will operate for a 1-year period, with the possibility of annual extensions by Congress for up to 1 year at a time.
